rows.REGRET MINIMIZATION FRAMEWORK: Bezos framework for big decisions - minimize regret at 80

"I wanted to project myself forward to age 80 and say, 'OK, I'm looking back on my 
life. I want to minimize the number of regrets I have.'

I knew that when I was 80, I was not going to regret having tried this. I was not 
going to regret trying to participate in this thing called the Internet that I 
thought was going to be a really big deal. I knew that if I failed, I wouldn't 
regret that. But I knew the one thing I might regret is not ever having tried."

— Jeff Bezos
Should we launch this business at all?
rows.col_2: Will I regret NOT trying to build this?
rows.col_3: Yes - the opportunity is real, the risk is manageable, the learning is valuable regardless

rows.REGRET MINIMIZATION FRAMEWORK: Should we spend $X on this ad test?
rows.col_2: Will I regret not knowing if this worked?
rows.col_3: Usually yes for reasonable amounts - information has value

rows.col_2: Will I regret not giving this person a chance?
rows.col_3: Consider both: regret of hiring wrong AND regret of not hiring right

rows.col_2: Will I regret diluting / Will I regret not having capital?
rows.col_3: Only raise if we'd regret not having the capital more than we'd regret dilution

rows.col_2: Will I regret not trying the new direction?
rows.col_3: If the current path isn't working, usually yes

rows.REGRET MINIMIZATION FRAMEWORK: • Facing a hard decision with no clear right answer
• Pros and cons list isn't helping
• The decision feels reversible but scary

rows.col_2: I did X and it didn't work

rows.col_3: The worst kind - avoid at all costs

rows.REGRET MINIMIZATION FRAMEWORK: "When I'm 80, looking back, will I regret NOT doing this?"
If yes → Do it. If no → Maybe don't. If unsure → Probably do it.
